title: Runes Reforged Will Be a Disaster
body:
If Riot doesn't have any plans to change the new player system (NOT talking about leveling) to implement thorough, explanatory tutorials for new players on most, if not all aspects of the game, this game will become a complete aneurysm for new players to figure out. 

It's already complicated enough, not to mention that the game itself is not straight forward and can take many paths, meaning players will not only have to figure out the basics but also figure out how to use strategy. 

Riot hasn't released ANY information at all on how they may change how new players learn the game when they create a new account (and no, the current tutorial is absolute garbage. It hasn't been changed in a long time and telling new players to build Thornmail on an ADC should explain the lack of clarity for new players). If they don't decide to try and do SOMETHING, Runes Reforged will completely deter new players trying to learn.

Sorry not sorry, it's true.


-Razor Blade174

replies.body: Good news: We have plans for the new player experience. Really new players won't be able to modify their runes and will instead get a default page that's generally appropriate to the champion they're playing. After they've played a small number of games they'll get to pick which of a series of pre-built pages they use. Then, after another set of games (still figuring out exactly how many) they'll get the ability to customize Rune pages like anyone else. They'll have a full set of runes worth of power from the start but won't have to deal with customizing the system until they've learned the basics of how the game works.

This is actually very clever. New players will be able to think, "Ok, why are these runes good on this champ?"

Although please dont leave it like the current game tutorial where you build {{item:3075}} on {{champion:22}}.

I love having 30% CDR/lvl runes and going Tear builds with only one CDR item like Zhonya's. Please don't take this away from me. It's really fun to make poke pages which normally don't scale well (such as Ziggs if you look at his late graph) do better. Since they're not burst assassins just going in for one rotation and then leaving, they absolutely need CDR but then if they get their normal CDR build they either don't have enough mana or they lack sufficient damage and die too fast as well. My solution is to lose the first 25 minutes and rely more on the jungler but allows me to remain relevant late (which is hard in this tankier shield/heal meta). I think the meta is fun personally... I like seeing more tanks but I see Adaptive Help vs me as Ziggs and it's already very hard so that's why I want these more scaling builds. Ziggs already won't solo kill people early if they're good and his waveclear isn't that amazing either (unless you use exorbitant mana) so I think I need to make him scale harder. I can't just take turrets and snowball every game. This 30% CDR build with Tear is my favorite by far and the only way to make Tear viable imo. If I don't go so many CDR runes, the Tear delays my own CDR way too much to be justified.

> [{quoted}](name=Douglas Funnie,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=qNw52AxA,comment-id=0006,timestamp=2017-09-02T23:32:51.436+0000)

I didn't imply anywhere that I want Riot to hold new players hands. But when you learn how to ride a bike, your parents have to help you a bit before you get the hang of it. Then you try on your own. And you may fall over. They help you back up, but they want you to succeed by learning. Similarly, I believe that tutorials for new players SHOULD be available for the basics of the game, and perhaps even basic strategy. The fact is, if I've never played a game like League before, and I jump into it with no prior knowledge of it at all, it's not going to be fun at all, because I will have no clue what I'm doing, and the current tutorials are of little/no help.

riot has to do this to keep interest in the end user without compromising the size of their player base.  make it too hard for people to get in, and you have what i call the "super smash bros melee" issue.  yes, people still get in and learn.  but its playerbase suffers ALOT from that steep learning curve.  Riot doesn't want to make the learning curve for league steeper than it already is, since it tends to deter new players and slows the growth of the player base.  you try to teach someone something or tell someone about something, and as soon as it gets "too complicated" or that learning curve to understand it gets a bit too steep, they lose interest.  Does that mean they are more of a part of the player base or interested in the topic than you? no.

Try learning how to play soccer by going onto a field full of pros playing at the pro level, and just watch how many people no longer want to play.  sure, you might not, but lots of other people that were somewhat interested before now are no longer.

Hum, the new system won't be worse for new players to learn than the current system. The current system is terribly bad, and the new one will be just as bad, but not WORSE. If anything, it might be *slightly* better, since Runes are unlocked at level 1 with a default page. So even if it's not *optimal* at least noobs will get a *decent* Rune Page, instead of nothing at all or using some noob-trap set-up like Crit Damage or the likes.
